required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Knee Aspiration and High Definition MRI for ACL Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study Into the Structural Local Molecular Environment Following an ACL Injury

lead_sponsor.agency: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of this pilot study is to understand the biological changes that occur within the knee joint following injury to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). This will be achieved through aspiration and analysis of the haemarthrosis which fills the knee following injury. The study will look at inflammatory and healing responses using DNA, RNA and protein analysis.
This, combined with high resolution imaging of the knee and surrounding soft tissue structures, may enable a more patient specific approach to treatment of ACL injury.

primary_outcome.measure: Pattern of injury on High Definition MRI measured by comparison with 3t MRI images
primary_outcome.description: Outcome will illustrate any additional benefit of high definition MRI

secondary_outcome.measure: Identification of acute inflammatory mediators measured by NanoString molecular analysis

intervention.intervention_name: Aspiration of haemarthrosis and high definition MRI
intervention.description: Aspiration of haemarthrosis and high definition MRI

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of ACL injury confirmed by MRI
- All participants must have the capacity to provide informed consent to participate
- Participants must be able to comply with required study visit
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants outside of the specified age range
- Participants who do not have the mental capacity to make informed decisions
- Participants who have meniscal pathology or other injuries requiring urgent surgery

facility.name: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
